div1.head: Military Orders for Aristides Agramonte, May 28, 1901
div1.p:
FROM THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES
Vol 61 - 1901
Agramonte

SPECIAL ORDERS, }
No. 117. }

HEADQUARTERS DEPARTMENT OF CUBA,
Havana, May 28, 1901.

1. Contract Surgeon Aristides Agramonte, U. S. Army,
having been relieved as a member of the board of medical
officers convened by paragraph 34, Special Orders No. 122,
series of 1900, Headquarters of the Army, is hereby as-
signed to duty in charge of the Department Laboratory at
Municipal Hospital No. 1, and of the microscopical and
bacteriological work at Las Animas Hospital in this city.

2. The Commanding Officer, Cabaña Barracks, Cuba,
will send under charge of Sergeant Jno. F. Hastings, 21st
company, Coast Artillery, and two (2) privates to be
designated by him, General Prisoner E. J. Justice, to Pinar
del Rio, where upon arrival he will be reported to the
President of the Audiencia now in session in that city.

When no longer required by the court the guard and
prisoner will return to their proper station, Cabaña Barracks.

Transportation and subsistence to be furnished from
Insular Funds.
The travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.

3. By direction of the Secretary of War, the following
named officers will report in person to Colonel William L.
Haskin, Artillery Corps, president of the examining board
convened at the Headquarters of the Artillery Defenses of
Havana, by paragraph 4, Special Orders No. 109, current
series, these Headquarters, at such time as they may be
required by the board for examination as to their fitness
for promotion; and upon completion thereof will return to
their proper stations:
1st Lieutenant D. E. Aultman, Artillery Corps;
1st Lieutenant H. F. Jackson, Artillery Corps;
1st Lieutenant H. La F. Applewhite, Artillery Corps;
2d Lieutenant W. P. Stokey, Artillery Corps;
2d Lieutenant U. Birnie, Jr., Artillery Corps.
The travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.

4. Private Thomas Kerwin, troop C, 7th Cavalry, having
been tried by a general court-martial convened at Columbia
Barracks, Cuba, for conduct to the prejudice of good order
and military discipline, in violation of the 62d Article of
War, was acquitted.
The acquittal is approved.

The prisoner will be released from confinement and re-
stored to duty.
